questions.text: A 38 year old gentleman came for the routine health check-up from his company. His blood pressure was 138/90 mmHg. In history, he was having occasional giddiness and perspirations. His previous history suggested occasional chest pain on exertion. He had a strong family history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.In view of his blood pressure reading, what would be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has a blood pressure reading of 138/90 mmHg. According to the WHO recommendation on blood pressure thresholds for pharmacological treatment, antihypertensives are recommended for individuals with existing cardiovascular disease and systolic blood pressure of 130-139 mmHg. They are also suggested for individuals without cardiovascular disease but with high cardiovascular risk, diabetes mellitus, or chronic kidney disease, and systolic blood pressure of 130-139 mmHg.
  • This patient has a diastolic blood pressure of 90 mmHg, which, regardless of other factors, meets the criteria for confirmed hypertension (systolic ≥140 mmHg or diastolic ≥90 mmHg) for initiation of pharmacological treatment.
  • Furthermore, his history of occasional giddiness, perspirations, and chest pain on exertion, along with a strong family history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, suggests potential existing cardiovascular risk and possibly diabetes, which further supports the initiation of antihypertensive treatment.

Explanation of Other Options:

Strict diet and lifestyle modification (Option A): Strict diet and lifestyle modification are important components of hypertension management and are often initiated concurrently with medication, but given his blood pressure and risk factors, medication is also indicated.

Reassurance and follow up (Option C): Reassurance alone is not appropriate for a patient with this blood pressure reading and risk factors, as it necessitates active management.

Ambulatory BP monitoring (Option D): Ambulatory BP monitoring is a useful tool for confirming hypertension and assessing blood pressure patterns over 24 hours. While valuable, it should not delay the initiation of treatment given the patient's blood pressure and risk factors, especially if there is existing end-organ damage or high blood pressure levels.

Key Takeaway:

Pharmacological antihypertensive treatment should be initiated for individuals with a confirmed diagnosis of hypertension (systolic ≥140 mmHg or diastolic ≥90 mmHg), or for those with systolic blood pressure of 130-139 mmHg if they have existing cardiovascular disease, high cardiovascular risk, diabetes mellitus, or chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady has dental phobia but has finally gone to the dentist following severe toothaches and is told she has dental abscesses. She is brought into the ER with high fevers by a relative. She is found to have a diastolic murmur in the aortic area. Which one of these is a sign of endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's history of dental abscesses (a potential source of bacteremia), high fever, and a new diastolic murmur (suggesting aortic regurgitation, often due to valvular damage) strongly points towards a diagnosis of infective endocarditis (IE).
  • Blood on urine dipstick (Option D) indicates renal involvement, which is a common manifestation of IE due to glomerulonephritis (an immunologic phenomenon) or microemboli originating from the vegetations.
  • Specifically, microemboli to the kidneys can cause microscopic hematuria, detected by a urine dipstick, and glomerulonephritis is a recognized complication of IE.

Explanation of Other Options:

Roslyn's Spot (Option A): It is not associated with infective endocarditis.

Hepatomegaly (Option B): While hepatomegaly can be a non-specific finding in various conditions including heart failure, splenomegaly is a more commonly associated sign in infective endocarditis due to immune complex deposition or splenic infarction.

Bouchard's nodes (Option C): Bouchard's nodes are bony enlargements on the proximal interphalangeal joints of the fingers, primarily associated with osteoarthritis, not infective endocarditis.

Key Takeaway:

In a patient suspected of infective endocarditis, blood on a urine dipstick is a significant finding indicating renal involvement due to microemboli or glomerulonephritis, which are common vascular or immunologic phenomena associated with the condition.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has tearing interscapular chest pain. His ECG shows no ST changes, but a CT scan with contrast showed aortic dissection. His blood pressure is 190/106 mmHg. Which is the most important management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with acute aortic dissection and severe hypertension, making aggressive blood pressure control the immediate and most important management step to reduce shear stress on the aorta and prevent further dissection propagation.
  • Intravenous labetalol (Option A) is an appropriate choice for this as it rapidly lowers blood pressure and heart rate.
  • Once blood pressure is controlled, the patient can be further assessed with coronary angiography or referred for urgent surgery.
  • Aortic Dissection Types:
    • Stanford Type A Aortic Dissection: This type occurs in the first part of the aorta, closer to the heart, and is immediately life-threatening. It usually requires emergency open chest surgery to repair or replace the affected segment, including the ascending aorta, possibly the arch, and/or aortic valve. Type A is more common than Type B, and the dissection often extends through the entire length of the aorta.
    • Stanford Type B Aortic Dissection: This tear begins farther down the aorta, in the descending aorta beyond the arch. It usually extends into the abdominal segment but does not involve the first part of the aorta. Surgery may or may not be needed immediately, depending on the dissection's location and if it affects blood flow to organs, often performed with a stent-graft device.
    • DeBakey Classification also defines types: Type 1 originates in the ascending aorta and extends downstream; Type 2 is limited to the ascending aorta (both similar to Stanford Type A); and Type 3 originates in the descending aorta and extends downward (similar to Stanford Type B).

Explanation of Other Options:

Ramipril (Option B): Ramipril is an oral ACE inhibitor used for long-term blood pressure control, with an onset of action too slow for acute management.

Refer for urgent cardiothoracic surgery (Option C): Urgent cardiothoracic surgery is crucial for Type A dissection, but initial blood pressure control is paramount before or concurrently with surgical preparation.

Echocardiography (Option D): Echocardiography is an important diagnostic tool, but a CT scan has already confirmed the diagnosis, making immediate blood pressure control the priority.

Key Takeaway:

In acute aortic dissection, aggressive control of blood pressure and heart rate using intravenous agents like labetalol is the most critical immediate management to reduce aortic shear stress and prevent further progression.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has worsening breathlessness. On examination, he has a systolic blood pressure of 115 mmHg which drops to 90mmHg during inspiration. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with worsening breathlessness and a significant drop in systolic blood pressure (from 115 mmHg to 90 mmHg) during inspiration. This drop of more than 10 mmHg during inspiration is the classic definition of pulsus paradoxus.
  • Cardiac tamponade (Option B) is the condition most likely to cause pulsus paradoxus. In cardiac tamponade, fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart and impairing its filling, especially the right ventricle during inspiration. This leads to reduced left ventricular stroke volume and a significant drop in systemic blood pressure during inspiration.

Explanation of Other Options:

Congestive cardiac failure (Option A): Congestive cardiac failure involves impaired pumping ability of the heart, leading to fluid overload and breathlessness, but pulsus paradoxus is not a characteristic finding.

Atrial fibrillation (Option C): Atrial fibrillation is an irregular and often rapid heart rhythm that can cause palpitations and shortness of breath, but it does not typically cause pulsus paradoxus.

Ventricular tachycardia (Option D): Ventricular tachycardia is a rapid heart rhythm originating in the ventricles that can lead to hemodynamic instability, but it is not associated with pulsus paradoxus.

Key Takeaway: The presence of pulsus paradoxus, defined as a drop in systolic blood pressure of more than 10 mmHg during inspiration, is a strong indicator of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 28-year woman who is 20 weeks pregnant is seen in the outpatient clinic and noted to have a sustained blood pressure of 180/95 mmHg. What is the most appropriate antihypertensive therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is 20 weeks pregnant with severe hypertension (180/95 mmHg), requiring pharmacological intervention.
  • Methyldopa (Option A) is considered a first-line and safe antihypertensive agent for use in pregnancy, particularly in the first and second trimesters.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hydrochlorthiazide (Option B): Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that can be used in pregnancy, but it is not generally preferred as a first-line agent for severe hypertension.

Amlodipine (Option C): Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker that can be used for hypertension in pregnancy, often as a second-line agent, and its safety profile is considered good.

Lisinopril (Option D): Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor, which is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its association with fetal renal dysfunction, oligohydramnios, and other severe fetal abnormalities, especially in the second and third trimesters.

Key Takeaway:

Methyldopa is considered the safest and most appropriate first-line antihypertensive therapy for severe hypertension during pregnancy, especially in the first and second trimesters, while ACE inhibitors like lisinopril are contraindicated.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to ER with severe acute chest pain radiating to the back. He is pale and anxious.On examination the blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg and he was noted to have blue sclerae. Which of the following conditions has predisposed to this complication?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with severe acute chest pain radiating to the back is highly suggestive of aortic dissection. The key distinguishing physical finding is blue sclerae.
  • Marfan's syndrome (Option D) is a connective tissue disorder known to predispose individuals to aortic dissection due to inherent weakness in aortic wall connective tissue. Blue sclerae are a characteristic ocular feature of Marfan's syndrome, along with other findings such as tall stature, arachnodactyly, and high-arched palate.
  • Aortic dissection and other cardiovascular problems remain the leading cause of death in Marfan's syndrome.
  • Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by a defect in the fibrillin-1 gene on chromosome 15. It is characterized by:
    • Tall stature with arm span to height ratio > 1.05
    • Upper to lower body ratio is decreased (head to symphysis pubis: symphysis pubis to toes).
    • High-arched palate
    • Arachnodactyly
    • Pectus excavatum
    • Pes planus
    • Scoliosis of > 20 degrees à Low back pain
    • Dural ectasia(ballooning of the dural sac at the lumbosacral level) - seen in 60% of patients. It may cause lower back pain associated with neurological problems such as bladder and bowel dysfunction like incontinence.
    • Heart-Dilatation of the aortic sinuses (seen in 90%) which may lead to aortic regurgitation, aortic aneurysm, aortic dissection, and mitral valve prolapse (75%) which causes systolic murmur at mitral area.
    • Lungs: repeatedpneumothoraxes
    • Eyes:Upwards lens dislocation(supertemporal ectopia lentis), blue sclera, retinal detachment and myopia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Coarctation of the aorta (Option A): Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing of the aorta that can lead to hypertension and increased risk of aneurysm or dissection.

Ischaemic heart disease (Option B): Ischaemic heart disease primarily involves narrowing of the coronary arteries, leading to angina and myocardial infarction.

Rheumatic fever (Option C): Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory disease that typically affects the heart valves, joints, brain, and skin, often following a streptococcal infection.

Key Takeaway:

The combination of symptoms suggestive of aortic dissection in a young patient with blue sclerae strongly points to an underlying connective tissue disorder like Marfan's syndrome, which predisposes to aortic fragility.

choices.text: Decrease vascular release of nitric oxide

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient has been commenced on nifedipine for hypertension. Which of the following effects describes the action of nifedipine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nifedipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (CCB), primarily acting as a potent vasodilator.
  • The main action of nifedipine in treating hypertension is smooth muscle relaxation in the arterioles, which leads to a reduction in peripheral vascular resistance (Option C). This vasodilation ultimately lowers blood pressure.

Explanation of Other Options:

Reduced sympathetic activity (Option A): Nifedipine causes increased sympathetic activity as a compensatory response to vasodilation and a drop in blood pressure.

Reduced peripheral capillary pressure (Option B): Nifedipine causes increased peripheral capillary pressure, which can lead to common side effects like ankle edema.

Decrease vascular release of nitric oxide (Option D): Nifedipine is associated with an increased vascular release of nitric oxide, which contributes to its vasodilatory effects.

Key Takeaway:

Nifedipine, a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, primarily acts by reducing peripheral vascular resistance through smooth muscle relaxation in arterioles, leading to its antihypertensive effect.

questions.text: A 80-year-old woman is referred by her GP for high blood pressure. Over the last three months her pressure has been recorded at around 175/80 mmHg for 3 occasions. She has a body mass index of 26 kg/m2 and is a non-smoker.Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for her blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is an 80-year-old woman with consistent high blood pressure readings of 175/80 mmHg, indicating isolated systolic hypertension.
  • For elderly patients with isolated systolic hypertension, calcium channel blockers (Option A) or diuretics are considered the most appropriate first-line treatments, as supported by guidelines and studies like SHEP (Systolic Hypertension in the Elderly Program).
  • Calcium channel blockers are particularly suitable for elderly patients who generally have poor arterial wall compliance and isolated systolic hypertension, as highlighted in the provided "Selection of first line antihypertensive drugs" image.

Explanation of Other Options:

Beta blocker (Option B): Beta blockers are effective antihypertensives, but are generally less preferred as first-line agents for isolated systolic hypertension in the elderly unless there are compelling indications like stable heart failure or post-MI.

Angiotensin Receptor Blocker (Option C): Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) are effective for hypertension, often used in patients who cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors, but they are not specifically highlighted as first-line for isolated systolic hypertension in the elderly over CCBs or diuretics.

Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) Inhibitor (Option D): ACE inhibitors are effective for hypertension and beneficial in conditions like heart failure or chronic kidney disease, but they are not universally preferred as first-line for isolated systolic hypertension in the elderly over CCBs or diuretics, especially considering potential side effects like cough or hyperkalemia.

Key Takeaway:

For elderly patients with isolated systolic hypertension, calcium channel blockers and diuretics are typically considered the most appropriate first-line antihypertensive therapies.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presented with chest pain, facial flushing and elevated jugular venous pressure but no leg oedema. He had been exposed to tuberculosis in childhood, had a strongly positive tuberculin test and had been followed up in the tuberculosis surveillance program with regular chest x-rays, but had never been diagnosed with tuberculosis. Chest x-ray on presentation showed calcified plaques and masses in the pericardium and mediastinum. Cardiac catheterization showed equalisation of diastolic pressures in all four chambers, with a positive square root sign. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with chest pain, elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP), and crucially, chest X-ray findings of calcified plaques and masses in the pericardium. The cardiac catheterization findings of equalization of diastolic pressures in all four chambers and a positive square root sign are pathognomonic for constrictive pericarditis (Option C).
  • The history of childhood TB exposure and a strongly positive tuberculin test suggests tuberculous pericarditis as a likely etiology, which is a known cause of constrictive pericarditis.
  • The atrial waveform in constrictive pericarditis manifests as an augmented "a" wave, a rapid "x" descent, and a steep "y" descent, all reflecting the stiff, unyielding pericardium.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pericardial effusion (Option A): Pericardial effusion is an accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, which can cause chest discomfort and elevated JVP, but the typical catheterization findings are not equalized diastolic pressures or a square root sign.

Cardiac tamponade (Option B): Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition where pericardial fluid causes significant compression of the heart, leading to impaired filling and reduced cardiac output, often presenting with pulsus paradoxus, but distinct from the chronic findings of constriction.

Sarcoidosis (Option D): Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that can affect the heart, leading to arrhythmias, heart failure, or infiltrative cardiomyopathy, but its primary cardiac manifestation is not typically constrictive pericarditis with these specific catheterization findings, although it can rarely cause it.

Key Takeaway: The definitive diagnostic signs for constrictive pericarditis on cardiac catheterization are equalization of diastolic pressures in all four cardiac chambers and the presence of a positive square root sign in the ventricular pressure tracing, often seen with pericardial calcification and a history of previous pericardial inflammation like tuberculous pericarditis.

choices.text: Loud diastolic murmur in the aortic area

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with central crushing chest pain radiating to the back. He has a weak pulse in the right arm and systolic BP is 120 mmHg in the left arm, 80 mmHg systolic in the right arm. Which one of the following is a feature of severity requiring immediate (surgical) action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with central crushing chest pain radiating to the back and a significant blood pressure differential between arms (differential pulses) is highly suggestive of aortic dissection.
  • A loud diastolic murmur in the aortic area (Option D) is a critical feature suggesting aortic regurgitation. This indicates that the dissection has extended to the aortic root and likely involves the aortic valve, leading to its incompetence.
  • Involvement of the aortic root or the presence of pericardial effusion (hemopericardium) are features of severe, complicated aortic dissection (often Stanford Type A) that necessitate immediate surgical intervention to prevent fatal complications.

Explanation of Other Options:

Persistent vomiting (Option A): Persistent vomiting is a non-specific symptom that can occur with severe pain or systemic illness but is not a direct indicator of a severe cardiac complication requiring immediate surgical action in aortic dissection.

Headache (Option B): Headache is a non-specific symptom that can occur in various conditions, including hypertension or anxiety, but it is not a direct indicator of a severe, surgically urgent complication in aortic dissection.

Pulmonary oedema on the CXR (Option C): Pulmonary oedema on a chest X-ray suggests left ventricular failure, which can occur in aortic dissection due to severe aortic regurgitation or myocardial ischemia. While a serious finding, the direct cause of the heart failure (e.g., severe aortic regurgitation indicated by the murmur) is the more specific and immediate trigger for surgical action.

Key Takeaway:
In a patient with suspected aortic dissection, the presence of a loud diastolic murmur in the aortic area is a critical sign indicating aortic root involvement and severe aortic regurgitation, which is a feature of complicated dissection requiring immediate surgical action.

questions.text: A 20 year old lady is short in stature for her age. She has a webbed neck and oligomenorrhoea. On physical examination, she heard a continuous murmur over the front of the chest as well as her back. A chest radiograph reveals a prominent left heart border and rib notching. Which of the following lesions best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's physical characteristics of short stature, webbed neck, and oligomenorrhoea are classic features of Turner syndrome.
  • The presence of a continuous murmur over the front of the chest and back, along with prominent left heart border and rib notching on chest radiograph, are highly indicative of Coarctation of the aorta (Option D). Rib notching specifically occurs due to erosion of the ribs by enlarged collateral blood vessels attempting to bypass the narrowed aortic segment.
  • Coarctation of the aorta is a common cardiovascular anomaly associated with Turner syndrome, second only to bicuspid aortic valve.

Explanation of Other Options:

Thoracic aortic aneurysm (Option A): A thoracic aortic aneurysm is a dilatation of the thoracic aorta, which may cause a murmur if very large or involving a valve, but does not typically present with rib notching or the systemic features of Turner syndrome.

Single large atrioventricular valve (Option B): A single large atrioventricular valve is a feature of atrioventricular septal defect, often associated with Down syndrome, and does not explain the continuous murmur or rib notching.

Supravalvular narrowing in aortic root (Option C): Supravalvular aortic narrowing involves constriction above the aortic valve, which can cause a systolic murmur and left ventricular hypertrophy but does not typically lead to rib notching or a continuous murmur over the back.

Key Takeaway:

The combination of Turner syndrome phenotypic features (short stature, webbed neck, oligomenorrhoea) with continuous murmur and classical rib notching on chest X-ray strongly indicates Coarctation of the aorta.

questions.text: Left atrial myxoma may be associated with all except-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A left atrial myxoma is the most common primary cardiac tumor, typically arising from the fossa ovalis.
  • A mid systolic click (Option B) is not associated with left atrial myxoma. A mid-systolic click is characteristic of mitral valve prolapse, caused by the sudden tensing of the chordae tendineae or valve leaflets during systole. In contrast, a left atrial myxoma can cause a mid-diastolic click (also known as a 'tumor plop'), which occurs when the tumor moves into the left ventricle during diastole and its motion abruptly stops.
  • Left atrial myxomas can be associated with sudden death, systemic emboli, and left atrial dilatation due to obstruction of blood flow.

Explanation of Other Options:

Sudden death (Option A): Left atrial myxomas can cause sudden death due to acute obstruction of the mitral valve orifice or systemic emboli to vital organs.

Systemic emboli (Option C): Left atrial myxomas frequently cause systemic emboli as fragments of the tumor or thrombi formed on its surface break off and travel to the systemic circulation.

Left atrial dilatation (Option D): Left atrial myxomas can cause left atrial dilatation due to the obstruction of blood flow across the mitral valve, leading to increased pressure and volume overload in the left atrium.

Key Takeaway: A left atrial myxoma is classically associated with a mid-diastolic click (tumor plop) due to obstruction, not a mid-systolic click, and can lead to serious complications such as sudden death, systemic emboli, and left atrial dilatation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old gentleman develops chest pain 7 minutes after fibreoptic bronchoscopy. The procedure had been performed without sedation following an intratracheal injection of 5 ml 2.5% cocaine solution and xylocaine spray to the pharynx for topical anaesthesia. ECG showed an evolving anterior myocardial infarction. Which of the following would you prefer for his management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient developed an acute myocardial infarction (MI) shortly after receiving cocaine solution, which is a known cardiotoxin. Cocaine-induced MIs are primarily caused by coronary artery spasm and vasoconstriction, rather than thrombosis.
  • Given this underlying mechanism, nitrates are the preferred initial treatment as they are potent vasodilators that can reverse coronary spasm, improving myocardial blood flow. Calcium channel antagonists are also appropriate in this setting.

Explanation of Other Options:

Beta blockers (Option A): Beta blockers are contraindicated in cocaine-induced chest pain or MI as they can lead to unopposed alpha-1 adrenergic action, potentially worsening coronary artery spasm.

Percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (Option C): Percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA) is a revascularization procedure used to open blocked coronary arteries. While it might be considered if initial medical therapy fails or if there is persistent evidence of occlusion, the primary acute management focuses on reversing spasm.

Thrombolysis with rt-PA (Option D): Thrombolysis with rt-PA is a fibrinolytic therapy used to dissolve blood clots in acute MI. However, since the primary mechanism of cocaine-induced MI is vasoconstriction and not primarily thrombosis, thrombolysis is less effective and not the initial preferred management.

Key Takeaway:

In cases of cocaine-induced myocardial infarction, the underlying mechanism is often coronary artery spasm and vasoconstriction. Therefore, vasodilators like nitrates or calcium channel blockers are the preferred initial management, and beta-blockers should be avoided.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with ischaemic heart disease is seen for review. He reports that he has developed some muscle aches and pains and you attribute this to a myalgia associated with simvastatin. His Creatinine kinase is within the normal range. However, his dyslipidaemia is still sub-optimal and you wish to add in a further agent. Which of the following agents would not be an appropriate additional therapy for this patient in view of his presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has ischemic heart disease, is on simvastatin, and has developed muscle aches (myalgia), suggesting a statin-induced side effect. His dyslipidemia remains suboptimal, requiring an additional agent.
  • Gemfibrozil is a fibrate that is contraindicated or should be avoided in combination with statins due to a significantly increased risk of statin-induced myositis and rhabdomyolysis, even at normal creatinine kinase levels. Therefore, it would not be an appropriate additional therapy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cholestyramine (Option A): Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant that can be used to lower LDL cholesterol, and it has a different mechanism of action from statins.

Ezetimibe (Option B): Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that effectively lowers LDL cholesterol and can be safely combined with statins.

Nicotinic acid (Option D): Nicotinic acid (Niacin) is a lipid-modifying agent that can lower LDL cholesterol, raise HDL cholesterol, and reduce triglycerides. While it can cause flushing, it is an option for dyslipidemia.

Key Takeaway:

When managing dyslipidemia in a patient experiencing statin-induced myalgia, co-administration of gemfibrozil with a statin is generally avoided due to a significantly increased risk of severe muscle adverse effects like myositis and rhabdomyolysis.

choices.text: Radiation of pain to the jaw
Relief of pain by sublingual nitrate

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presented with intermittent chest pain at rest. Which one of the following would most strongly suggest that the pain was due to myocardial ischaemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with intermittent chest pain at rest, raising suspicion for myocardial ischemia.
  • Radiation of pain to the jaw is a highly characteristic and relatively specific feature of myocardial ischemia. This phenomenon occurs due to nerve convergence, where sensory nerves from the heart and the jaw converge at similar points in the spinal cord, leading to referred pain.

Explanation of Other Options:

Coexistent claudication (Option A): Coexistent claudication suggests the presence of peripheral vascular disease, which is a risk factor for cardiovascular disease but not a specific indicator of myocardial ischemia.

Past history of cigarette smoking (Option B): A past history of cigarette smoking is a significant risk factor for the development of cardiovascular disease, but it does not specifically confirm that the current chest pain is ischemic.

Relief of pain by sublingual nitrate (Option D): Relief of pain by sublingual nitrate is a common feature of myocardial ischemia, but it can also relieve pain from other conditions, such as esophageal spasm, making it less specific than jaw radiation.

Key Takeaway: While several factors can suggest cardiac involvement, radiation of chest pain to the jaw is a particularly strong and relatively specific indicator of myocardial ischemia due to nerve convergence.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the clinic having had 5 blackouts over the last year, all while she is standing up. She gets warnings of blurred vision, nausea, and feeling hot. She had been witnessed twice to have jerking of all limbs while she was unconscious. The attacks last 30-60 seconds. She recovers quickly after the attacks. She has never bitten her tongue or sustained any injuries. Physical examination and an ECG are normal. Her grandmother and sister suffer from epilepsy. Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's history of blackouts while standing, with prodromal symptoms of blurred vision, nausea, and feeling hot, followed by quick recovery, strongly suggests vasovagal syncope. The witnessed jerking of limbs is a common feature in syncope due to cerebral hypoxia, and the absence of tongue biting or injuries further supports syncope over epilepsy.
  • Given these classic features of vasovagal syncope, a tilt table test is the most appropriate investigation. It is a useful test specifically designed to reproduce the conditions that trigger vasovagal syncope and confirm the diagnosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

EEG (Option A): An EEG (electroencephalogram) is used to evaluate brain activity and diagnose seizure disorders, but the clinical presentation is more indicative of syncope than epilepsy.

24 hour ECG recording (Option B): A 24-hour ECG recording (Holter monitor) is used to detect cardiac arrhythmias that might cause syncope. While cardiac causes of syncope exist, the prodromal symptoms and triggers (standing) are more classic for vasovagal syncope.

CT brain (Option C): A CT brain scan is used to detect structural abnormalities in the brain, such as tumors or stroke, and is less likely to yield a diagnosis for this presentation.

Key Takeaway:

When a patient presents with recurrent blackouts characterized by triggers like standing, gradual onset prodromal symptoms (e.g., blurred vision, nausea, hot sensation), brief unconsciousness with possible jerking, and rapid recovery, vasovagal syncope is the most likely diagnosis, and a tilt table test is the most appropriate diagnostic investigation.

choices.text: A normal ECG excludes the diagnosis
Embolectomy is more effective than thrombolysis in improving survival
Heparin is as effective as thrombolytic therapy
Thrombolysis administered through a peripheral vein is as effective as through a pulmonary artery catheter

questions.text: Which one of the following is true regarding acute pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Thrombolysis administered through a peripheral vein is as effective as through a pulmonary artery catheter when treating acute pulmonary embolism. Thrombolytic therapy is typically reserved for patients with severely compromised circulation.
  • The results of trials in submassive PE, comparing thrombolytic agents (like tenecteplase) versus heparin alone, showed a reduction in death or hemodynamic collapse in the thrombolytic group.

Explanation of Other Options:

A normal ECG excludes the diagnosis (Option A): Most patients with pulmonary embolism have normal ECGs, indicating that a normal ECG does not exclude the diagnosis.

Embolectomy is more effective than thrombolysis in improving survival (Option B): Embolectomies are rarely performed nowadays due to the excellent results achieved with thrombolysis.

Heparin is as effective as thrombolytic therapy (Option C): Heparin reduces the risk of further embolism and pulmonary vasoconstriction. However, thrombolytic therapy has been shown to reduce death or hemodynamic collapse more effectively than heparin alone in cases of submassive PE.

Key Takeaway:

In acute pulmonary embolism, thrombolytic therapy is effective whether administered peripherally or via a pulmonary artery catheter, particularly for patients with compromised circulation. Heparin primarily prevents further clotting, while thrombolytics actively dissolve existing clots, offering superior benefit in specific severe cases.

choices.text: Has a positive inotropic effect on ischaemic myocardium
Improves oxygen release to the tissues

questions.text: Which of the following concerning the use of intravenous bicarbonate in cardiorespiratory arrest is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • The use of intravenous bicarbonate in cardiorespiratory arrest, particularly if hypercapnia occurs, can exacerbate intracellular acidosis because CO2 produced can easily cross cell membranes, leading to a further decrease in intracellular pH.
  • While bicarbonate therapy can increase extracellular pH, this is only effective if the CO2 produced can be adequately removed by ventilation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Has a positive inotropic effect on ischaemic myocardium (Option B): Sodium bicarbonate has a negative inotropic effect on the myocardium.

Improves oxygen release to the tissues (Option C): Sodium bicarbonate shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to the left, which inhibits oxygen release to the tissues.

Increases cerebral blood flow (Option D): Sodium bicarbonate reduces cerebral blood flow.

Key Takeaway:

Intravenous bicarbonate in cardiorespiratory arrest, without adequate ventilation, can paradoxically worsen intracellular acidosis and has other negative effects such as reducing myocardial contractility and impairing oxygen release to tissues.

choices.text: Constriction of the aorta past the ductus arteriosus
Lack of development of the spiral septum and partial absence of conus musculature
Shortening and thickening of chordae tendineae of the mitral valve

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl is short in stature for her age. She has not shown any changes of puberty. She has a webbed neck. Her vital signs include - Temperature 36.6oC, Respiratory rate 18/min. Pulse 78 bpm and BP 160/86 mmHg. On physical examination, she has a continuous murmur heard over both the front of the chest as well as her back. Her lower extremities are cool with poor capillary filling. A chest radiograph reveals a prominent left heart border, no oedema or effusions, and rib notching. Which of the following pathologic lesions best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with short stature, webbed neck, and absent pubertal changes are classic features of Turner syndrome.
  • The physical examination findings of hypertension (BP 160/86 mmHg), a continuous murmur over the chest and back, cool lower extremities with poor capillary filling, and a chest radiograph showing prominent left heart border and rib notching are pathognomonic for coarctation of the aorta.
  • Constriction of the aorta past the ductus arteriosus (Option A), also known as postductal coarctation, precisely describes the anatomical lesion consistent with these findings, allowing for prolonged survival and the development of collateral circulation causing rib notching. Coarctation of the aorta is one of the common cardiac defects associated with Turner syndrome.

Turner's syndrome (45,X0):

  • Cause: Presence of only one sex chromosome (X) or a deletion of the short arm of one of the X chromosomes.
  • General Features: Short stature, shield chest with widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, primary amenorrhea, associated absent uterus and streak ovaries, cystic hygroma (often diagnosed prenatally), high-arched palate, short fourth metacarpal, multiple pigmented nevi, keloid scars, and lymphedema in neonates (especially feet).
  • Cardiac Defects: Common cardiac defects include bicuspid aortic valve (15%) and coarctation of the aorta (5-10%).
  • Associated Conditions: Includes autoimmune diseases (e.g., autoimmune thyroiditis with common hypothyroidism), Crohn's disease, and a strong association with horseshoe kidney.
  • Hypertension: Quite common and typically idiopathic (essential hypertension); in a small proportion, the cause can include coarctation of the aorta and renal dysfunction due to a horseshoe kidney.
  • Other Associations: Metabolic abnormalities (dyslipidemia and glucose intolerance) and recurrent otitis media.
  • Diagnosis: Made by karyotype identification of 45X0.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lack of development of the spiral septum and partial absence of conus musculature (Option B): This describes anatomical defects seen in conditions like Tetralogy of Fallot or Truncus Arteriosus, which involve cyanotic heart disease and different clinical features.

Shortening and thickening of chordae tendineae of the mitral valve (Option C): This pathology describes features of mitral stenosis or regurgitation, which can cause murmurs and cardiac enlargement, but do not explain rib notching or the specific circulatory findings of coarctation.

Single large atrioventricular valve (Option D): A single large atrioventricular valve is characteristic of atrioventricular septal defect, commonly seen in Down syndrome, and would not explain the continuous murmur over the back or rib notching.

Key Takeaway:

The constellation of Turner syndrome phenotypic features combined with hypertension, differential pulses/cool lower extremities, a continuous murmur, and characteristic rib notching on chest X-ray strongly indicates Coarctation of the aorta, typically postductal, which results from a constriction of the aorta.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man presented with acute pain, pallor and absent pulses in his right leg. Investigations revealed an embolus in his femoral artery. What is the most likely source of this embolus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is a 78-year-old man presenting with acute limb ischemia (pain, pallor, absent pulses in the right leg) due to a femoral artery embolus. In this age group, atherosclerosis is a prevalent condition.
  • The most likely source of this embolus is thrombi from an atheromatous aorta . Ulceration of an atheromatous plaque in the abdominal aorta is a common source of peripheral arterial emboli.

Explanation of Other Options:

Paradoxical emboli (Option A): Paradoxical emboli occur when a venous thrombus crosses from the right to the left side of the heart through a septal defect (e.g., PFO).

Rheumatic endocardial vegetations (Option B): Rheumatic endocardial vegetations are typically associated with rheumatic heart disease, a less common cause of emboli in this age group compared to atherosclerosis.

Right ventricular thrombi (Option C): Right ventricular thrombi would typically embolize to the pulmonary circulation, causing pulmonary embolism, not systemic arterial occlusion.

Key Takeaway:

In elderly patients presenting with acute limb ischemia due to an arterial embolus, the most common source is usually thrombi originating from an atheromatous aorta.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female is noted to have sustained hypertension with a blood pressure of 196/80 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is a 75-year-old female with sustained isolated systolic hypertension (196/80 mmHg).
  • Beta blockers are less effective in this age group than in younger patients (Option C). This patient has isolated systolic hypertension, and there is evidence that beta blockers may be less effective in elderly patients. For isolated systolic hypertension in those over 60, calcium-channel blockers and thiazide diuretics are suggested as first-choice drugs.

Explanation of Other Options:

ACE inhibitors would be contraindicated in association with a creatinine above 1.5 mg/dl (Option A): ACE inhibitors are not contraindicated when the serum creatinine is greater than 1.5 mg/dl, but should be commenced under specialist supervision.

Antihypertensive therapy would be associated with only a minor reduction in risk of stroke in this age group (Option B): Elderly patients have a higher absolute cardiovascular risk than younger individuals and therefore benefit more from control of blood pressure, including a reduction in the risk of stroke and coronary events.

Doxazosin would be the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient (Option D): Doxazosin, an alpha-blocker, is not generally considered the most appropriate initial treatment for isolated systolic hypertension in the elderly. Calcium channel blockers and thiazide diuretics are typically preferred first-line agents in this demographic.

Key Takeaway:

For elderly patients with isolated systolic hypertension, beta blockers are generally less effective as first-line therapy compared to calcium channel blockers or thiazide diuretics, which are preferred given the higher absolute cardiovascular risk in this age group.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with hypertension. Which of the following statements concerning hypertension in the young is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aortic coarctation is the commonest secondary cause of hypertension in the young, when considering non-renal causes. Renal abnormalities, especially reflux-associated scarring, are the commonest overall secondary causes.

Explanation of Other Options:

Sodium nitroprusside is useful for the long-term treatment of severe cases (Option A): Sodium nitroprusside is useful only for short-term management due to the risk of cyanide accumulation with prolonged use.

It is defined as systolic blood pressure above the 99th centile for age (Option B): Hypertension in the young is typically defined as systolic blood pressure above the 95th centile for age, not the 99th centile.

Abnormalities are frequently seen on DMSA scan (Option C): Abnormalities are frequently seen on DMSA scan due to renal abnormalities like reflux-associated scarring, which is the commonest renal cause, but the question asks about the commonest secondary cause overall which includes coarctation as the commonest non-renal one.

Key Takeaway:

In young individuals with hypertension, aortic coarctation is the commonest non-renal secondary cause, while renal abnormalities (often identified by DMSA scan) are the most frequent overall secondary causes.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female with Turner syndrome is referred by the GP concerned about her blood pressure which he has found to be persistently elevated at between 140-160/90 mmHg. On examination she is noted to have a blood pressure of 148/92 mmHg, with no radio-femoral delay and no murmur audible. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her hypertension?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has Turner syndrome and presents with persistently elevated blood pressure (140-160/90 mmHg). While coarctation of the aorta is associated with Turner syndrome, the examination notes no radio-femoral delay and no murmur audible.
  • Given the absence of these classic signs of coarctation, essential hypertension is the most likely cause. Hypertension is quite common in Turner syndrome (occurring in about 10% of cases) and is typically idiopathic.

Explanation of Other Options:

Coarctation of the aorta (Option A): Coarctation of the aorta is a common cardiac anomaly in Turner syndrome but would typically present with radio-femoral delay and a continuous murmur, which are absent in this case.

Primary hyperaldosteronism (Option C): Primary hyperaldosteronism is a cause of secondary hypertension but is not specifically more common in Turner syndrome compared to essential hypertension, and its diagnosis would require specific biochemical tests.

Renal artery stenosis (Option D): Renal artery stenosis is a cause of secondary hypertension, and while renal dysfunction (e.g., due to horseshoe kidney) can occur in Turner syndrome, renal artery stenosis is not typically the most likely cause of hypertension in the absence of other specific indicators like abdominal bruits.

Key Takeaway:

In patients with Turner syndrome and hypertension, essential hypertension is the most likely cause, particularly when classic signs of coarctation of the aorta (like radio-femoral delay and characteristic murmurs) are absent.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man takes atenolol for hypertension. Which of the following side effects is he most likely to be aware of two hours after taking atenolol?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is taking atenolol, a beta-blocker, for hypertension.
  • Fatigue is a frequent and commonly reported side effect of beta-blockers like atenolol, and its onset would typically be felt within two hours and persist beyond after taking the drug.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hesitancy of micturition (Option B): Hesitancy of micturition is not a typical side effect of atenolol; it is more commonly associated with conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia or alpha-adrenergic agonists.

Nausea (Option C): Nausea is not a commonly reported side effect of atenolol.

Orthostatic hypotension (Option D): While antihypertensives can cause orthostatic hypotension, atenolol is a beta-blocker and would be unlikely to produce significant postural hypotension in a hypertensive subject in the absence of other factors.

Key Takeaway:

Among the listed options, fatigue is the most likely and commonly experienced side effect two hours after taking atenolol, a beta-blocker.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a 5-year history of type II diabetes mellitus presents for annual review with a blood pressure of 188/88 mmHg. Clinical examination was normal. An ECG reveals evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy. Which one of the following drugs is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's hypertension?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is a 70-year-old male with type II diabetes, isolated systolic hypertension (188/88 mmHg), and evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) on ECG. LVH is considered a complication of hypertension.
  • For a diabetic patient with LVH, there is compelling evidence to suggest that an ACE inhibitor or an Angiotensin II Receptor Blocker (ARB) should be the first-line treatment for hypertension.
  • Valsartan is an Angiotensin II Receptor Blocker (ARB) and is therefore the most appropriate choice given the patient's diabetes and LVH.

Explanation of Other Options:

Atenolol (Option A): Atenolol is a beta-blocker that is effective for hypertension, but for elderly patients with isolated systolic hypertension, calcium channel blockers or thiazides are often preferred. Beta blockers may also be less effective in elderly patients.

Amlodipine (Option B): Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker, which is a suitable first-line option for isolated systolic hypertension in the elderly and for patients with LVH. However, in a diabetic patient with LVH, ARBs or ACE inhibitors are considered to have compelling evidence as first-line.

Bendroflumethiazide (Option C): Bendroflumethiazide is a thiazide diuretic that is suitable for isolated systolic hypertension and low-cost therapy. While a valid option for isolated systolic hypertension in the elderly, ARBs or ACE inhibitors are specifically indicated first-line for diabetic patients with LVH.

Key Takeaway:

In a patient with isolated systolic hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and left ventricular hypertrophy, an Angiotensin II Receptor Blocker (ARB) or an ACE inhibitor is the most appropriate first-line antihypertensive therapy due to compelling evidence of their benefits in these specific conditions.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents after taking an overdose of her grandmother's medication. Investigations revealed: Serum potassium 6 mmol/L (3.5-4.9). Which one of the following drugs is the most likely cause of this abnormality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presented with an overdose and subsequent hyperkalemia (serum potassium 6 mmol/L).
  • Propranolol, a beta-blocker, is the most likely cause of this abnormality in overdose. Beta-blockers, particularly propranolol, can cause hyperkalemia through transmembrane shifts.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aspirin (Option A): Aspirin overdose, specifically salicylate overdose, typically causes metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis.

Digoxin (Option B): Digoxin overdose most commonly manifests as rhythm disturbance, and its effects may be exacerbated by hyper- or hypokalemia.

Salbutamol (Option C): Salbutamol, a beta-agonist, is known to cause hypokalemia, which is the opposite effect of hyperkalemia.

Key Takeaway:

In overdose, beta-blockers, such as propranolol, can cause hyperkalemia due to transmembrane shifts, a mechanism opposite to that of beta-agonists which typically cause hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male is admitted with a blood pressure of 210/120 and episodic runs of ventricular tachycardia. Investigations confirm the presence of a right adrenal phaeochromocytoma. Which one of the following would be the most appropriate initial therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with severe hypertension and ventricular tachycardia due to a confirmed phaeochromocytoma, which involves excessive catecholamine release.
  • The most appropriate initial therapy is to block the alpha-adrenergic effects of the catecholamines to control the severe hypertension and prevent a hypertensive crisis.
  • Phenoxybenzamine is an alpha-blocker, and the patient should initially be started on alpha-blockers before beta-blockers are introduced. This initial alpha-blockade is crucial to prevent unopposed alpha-adrenergic vasoconstriction if beta-blockers are given first.

Explanation of Other Options:

Amlodipine (Option A): Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker that is effective for hypertension, but alpha-blockade is the initial priority in phaeochromocytoma to prevent unopposed alpha-adrenergic effects.

Atenolol (Option B): Atenolol is a beta-blocker. Beta-blockers should only be introduced after adequate alpha-blockade in phaeochromocytoma to avoid precipitating a hypertensive crisis from unopposed alpha-receptor stimulation.

Lidocaine (Option C): Lidocaine can be acutely used for sustained ventricular tachycardia, but the most appropriate initial therapy for the underlying phaeochromocytoma's effects (hypertension and arrhythmias) is alpha-blockade.

Key Takeaway: In a patient with phaeochromocytoma presenting with severe hypertension and ventricular tachycardia, initial management with an alpha-blocker like phenoxybenzamine is paramount to control blood pressure and prevent unopposed alpha-adrenergic effects before introducing beta-blockers.

questions.text: A study reveals an immediate rise in blood pressure following infusion of a hormone in normal volunteers. Which of the following is the most likely hormone used in this study?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Angiotensin II is a potent vasoconstrictor and, when infused intravenously, produces an immediate rise in blood pressure. This is its primary physiological action as part of the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS).

Explanation of Other Options:

Prolactin (Option A): Prolactin is a hormone primarily involved in lactation and has no specific effect on immediate blood pressure regulation.

Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) (Option C): Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) primarily functions to lower blood pressure and promote natriuresis (sodium excretion).

Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) (Option D): Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) also functions to lower blood pressure and promote natriuresis, similar to ANP.

Key Takeaway:

Angiotensin II is the most likely hormone to cause an immediate rise in blood pressure upon infusion, as it is a powerful vasoconstrictor.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male is referred to with impotence. He has a history of angina, hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Which one of the following drugs that he takes would present a contraindication to him being able to receive Sildenafil?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Isosorbide Mononitrate is a nitrate. Nitrates and Sildenafil are absolutely contraindicated for co-administration due to the risk of precipitous and severe drops in blood pressure. This can lead to profound hypotension, syncope, and myocardial ischemia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aspirin (Option A): Aspirin is an antiplatelet agent commonly used in patients with angina and a history of ischemic heart disease. There is no contraindication to combining aspirin with sildenafil.

Bendroflumethiazide (Option B): Bendroflumethiazide is a thiazide diuretic used for hypertension. There is no contraindication to combining this diuretic with sildenafil, although careful blood pressure monitoring is always advised with any antihypertensive.

Ramipril (Option D): Ramipril is an ACE inhibitor used for hypertension and in patients with ischemic heart disease or diabetes. There is no contraindication to combining an ACE inhibitor with sildenafil, though blood pressure should be monitored.

Key Takeaway: Nitrates, such as isosorbide mononitrate, are a strict contraindication to the use of sildenafil due to the dangerous risk of a severe and sudden drop in blood pressure.
